# When talking about Chemical Engineering, what is a mole?

## Definition

- Mole = mass equivalent of the molar mass of a molecule

::: {.fragment .centered .higher}
![](./O_C_O.png){width="50%"}
:::

::: {.fragment .centered .evenhigher}
molar mass $\mathrm{CO_2}$: $44.010$
:::

::: {.fragment .leftarrow}
 gram-mol equivalent $\swarrow$
:::

::: {.fragment .leftarrow2}
1 gram-mol $\mathrm{CO_2} \rightarrow$ 44.010 grams
:::

::: {.fragment .rightarrow}
$\searrow$ lb-mol equivalent
:::

::: {.fragment .rightarrow2}
1 lb-mol $\mathrm{CO_2} \rightarrow$ 44.010 $\mathrm{lb_m}$
:::

## How many different types of moles are there?

- 15 mass units on N.I.S.T website $\rightarrow$ at least 15 types of moles
- range: carat-mole — pennyweight-mole
- Most common moles are:
  - $\text{g-mol}$ or $\text{mole}$
  - $\text{kg-mol}$ or $\text{kilomole}$
  - $\text{metric-ton-mole}$ or $\text{tonne-mole}$
  - $\text{lb-mol}$
  - $\text{ton-mole}$


# How do you use a mole?

## Using a Mole
::: {.high}
- Start with a balanced chemical equation.
:::

::: {.fragment .centered .higher}
 $\mathrm{C} + \mathrm{O_2} \rightarrow \mathrm{CO_2}$
:::

::: {.lower} 
- To make $100\ \mathrm{lb_m}$ of $\mathrm{CO_2}$:
:::

::: {.fragment}
![](./Line.png){.absolute top=175 left=380 width="50" height="15"}
:::

::: {.fragment}
![](./Line.png){.absolute top=175 left=470 width="50" height="15"}
:::

::: {.fragment}
![](./Pt1.png){.absolute top=195 left=360 width="100" height="50"}
:::

::: {.fragment}
![](./Pt2.png){.absolute top=195 left=470 width="100" height="50"}
:::

::: {.fragment}
![](./Pt3.png){.absolute top=195 left=570 width="100" height="50"}
:::

::: {.fragment .centered .evenhigher}
 molar mass of $\mathrm{CO_2}$ $\rightarrow$ $44.009546$, rounds to $44.010$
:::

::: {.high}
  - $100\ \mathrm{lb_m\ CO_2} \cdot \frac{1\text{ lb-mol }\mathrm{CO_2}}{44.010\text{ }\mathrm{lb_m}} = 2.272\ \text{lb-mol}$ of $\mathrm{CO_2}$
  - 1:1:1 molar ratio:
    - $2.272\ \text{lb-mol C}$
    - $2.272\ \text{lb-mol }\mathrm{O_2}$
:::

::: {.fragment .eqn1}
$\cdot 12.011\ \frac{\mathrm{lb_m\ C}}{\text{lb-mol}} = 27.29  \mathrm{lb_m\ C}$
:::

::: {.fragment .eqn2}
$\cdot 31.999\ \frac{\mathrm{lb_m\ O}_2}{\text{lb-mol}} = 72.70  \mathrm{lb_m\ O}_2$
:::

# What is Avogadro's number?

## Avogadro's Number

:::{.fragment .absolute top=185 left=50 width="450" height="300"}
The Avogadro Constant/ Avogadro's Number:
:::

:::{.fragment .absolute top=215 left=520}
$6.02214076 \times 10^{23}\ \frac{\mathrm{molecules}}{\mathrm{mol}}$
:::

:::{.fragment .absolute top=390 left=100 width="450" height="300"}
$\text{lb-mol}$ constant:
:::

:::{.fragment .absolute top=385 left=450}
 $1.327 654 687 336 \times 10^{27}\ \frac{\mathrm{molecules}}{\text{lb-mol}}$

:::


# Why can’t I just use the mole that I’m familiar with?

## Use the Correct Moles

- Unless the problem is in grams, don't use gram moles!
- $\underline{Inefficient}$ steps for using gram moles:
  - Start with mass in units other than grams.
    1. Convert to grams.
    2. Convert to gram-moles.
    3. Use balanced chemical equation to solve for the other species in gram-moles.
    4. Convert the other species' gram-moles to grams.
    5. Convert the grams to the starting mass species.
- Requires five steps.

## Use the Correct Moles

- Unless the problem is in grams, don't use gram moles!
- $\underline{Efficient}$ steps for using moles:
  - Start with mass in units other than grams.
    1. Convert to  the mass unit's moles.
    2. Use balanced chemical equation to solve for the other species in the mass unit's moles.
    3. Convert the other species' moles to mass units.
- Requires three steps instead of five.
- 40% fewer places to make mistakes!


## The Takeaways

1. Different types of moles are for different types of mass units.
2. The molar mass is just the conversion factor between moles and mass. It has the same numerical value for all mass/mole pairs.
3. Use gram moles for problems in grams. Use pound-moles for problems in pounds, etc.
